elements.content: Synthesis and gas sorption properties of a novel fluorinated metal−organic framework using commercially available 2,2-bis(4-carboxyphenyl)hexafluoropropane is reported with high selectivity toward CO2, H2S, and SO2 as well as breathing motion upon solvent removal and gas inclusion.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis and gas sorption properties of a novel fluorinated metal-organic framework using commercially available 2,2-bis(4-carboxyphenyl)hexafluoropropane is reported with high selectivity toward CO2, H2S, and SO2 as well as breathing motion upon solvent removal and gas inclusion.

elements.content: Synthesis and gas sorption properties of a novel fluorinated metal−organic framework using commercially available 2,2-bis(4-carboxyphenyl)hexafluoropropane is reported with high selectivity toward CO2, H2S, and SO2 as well as breathing motion upon solvent removal and gas inclusion.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis and gas sorption properties of a novel fluorinated metal-organic framework using commercially available 2,2-bis(4-carboxyphenyl)hexafluoropropane is reported with high selectivity toward CO2, H2S, and SO2 as well as breathing motion upon solvent removal and gas inclusion.

elements.content: In the past decade, the self-assembled construction of novel functional metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) has aroused worldwide interest in the fields of crystal engineering and material chemistry. This is due to the variety of architectures that can be generated with significant porosity and thus high surface area. As a result, diverse applications in gas separation and storage, and chemical catalysis have been reported. In this regard, fluorous metal−organic frameworks (FMOFs) are a new class of porous materials that show enhanced thermal stability and low surface tension in addition to other excellent optical and electrical properties. Omary and co-workers have recently communicated the first example of FMOF derived from silver(I) and 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)-1,2,4-triazolate (Tz) to yield FMOF-1, which shows a unique hysteretic sorption of H2 and high uptake of O2. Nevertheless, very few publications dealing with the synthesis of MOFs with fluorinated ligands are available, and, surprisingly, the use of FMOFs for capture of carbon dioxide and other toxic gases has not been reported despite the fact that perfluorinated compounds have shown unusual favorable electrostatic interactions with CO2. Similarly, MOFs with flexible ligands have been shown to provide some intriguing properties such as breathing phenomena in the solid state. Understanding what causes these materials to respond to external stimuli can have applications in the development of smart materials. Herein, we report the synthesis, gas separation, and breathing properties of a flexible FMOF obtained by the self-assembly of 2,2′-bis(4-carboxyphenyl)hexafluoropropane (1) and zinc nitrate hexahydrate (FMOF-2). To our knowledge, this is the first breathing FMOF tested for CO2 sorption and other acid gas removal applications.
elements.clean_text: In the past decade, the self-assembled construction of novel functional metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has aroused worldwide interest in the fields of crystal engineering and material chemistry. This is due to the variety of architectures that can be generated with significant porosity and thus high surface area. As a result, diverse applications in gas separation and storage, and chemical catalysis have been reported. In this regard, fluorous metal-organic frameworks (FMOFs) are a new class of porous materials that show enhanced thermal stability and low surface tension in addition to other excellent optical and electrical properties. Omary and co-workers have recently communicated the first example of FMOF derived from silver(I) and 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)-1,2,4-triazolate (Tz) to yield FMOF-1, which shows a unique hysteretic sorption of H2 and high uptake of O2. Nevertheless, very few publications dealing with the synthesis of MOFs with fluorinated ligands are available, and, surprisingly, the use of FMOFs for capture of carbon dioxide and other toxic gases has not been reported despite the fact that perfluorinated compounds have shown unusual favorable electrostatic interactions with CO2. Similarly, MOFs with flexible ligands have been shown to provide some intriguing properties such as breathing phenomena in the solid state. Understanding what causes these materials to respond to external stimuli can have applications in the development of smart materials. Herein, we report the synthesis, gas separation, and breathing properties of a flexible FMOF obtained by the self-assembly of 2,2'-bis(4-carboxyphenyl)hexafluoropropane (1) and zinc nitrate hexahydrate (FMOF-2). To our knowledge, this is the first breathing FMOF tested for CO2 sorption and other acid gas removal applications.

elements.content: Colorless crystals of FMOF-2 (chemical formula C29H19F9NO8.25Zn2) was obtained by heating a DMF and ethanol solution containing 1 and zinc nitrate hexahydrate in a 1:1 ratio at 110 °C for several hours. Crystallographic measurements of the resulting crystals confirm the flexible V-shaped organic building block was connected to two zinc atoms to generate a 2-fold interpenetrated framework filled with coordinated DMF and ethanol molecules (Figure ). The zinc clusters and V-shaped building blocks self-assemble to form a porous framework with two different cavities that contain a molecular square composed of two tetrazinc clusters and two molecules of 1 (). The framework also contains a helical structure composed of tetrazinc clusters and two molecules of 1 with a void space of 133 Å3 running along the b-axis after removing one of the ethanol molecules and contains extra void space after removing the coordinated DMF molecule, in which fluorinated groups line the cavity (Figure , ). The framework topology may be reduced by viewing the zinc cluster as a hexacoordinate antiprism in which four zinc atoms are connected to six carboxylate groups of 1. Figure illustrates one octahedron bound to six organic building blocks, and the repetition of the same unit in three dimensions results in a framework, which is complicated by the presence of two identical, interpenetrating strands ().
elements.clean_text: Colorless crystals of FMOF-2 (chemical formula C29H19F9NO8.25Zn2) was obtained by heating a DMF and ethanol solution containing 1 and zinc nitrate hexahydrate in a 1:1 ratio at 110 °C for several hours. Crystallographic measurements of the resulting crystals confirm the flexible V-shaped organic building block was connected to two zinc atoms to generate a 2-fold interpenetrated framework filled with coordinated DMF and ethanol molecules (Figure ). The zinc clusters and V-shaped building blocks self-assemble to form a porous framework with two different cavities that contain a molecular square composed of two tetrazinc clusters and two molecules of 1 (). The framework also contains a helical structure composed of tetrazinc clusters and two molecules of 1 with a void space of 133 Å3 running along the b-axis after removing one of the ethanol molecules and contains extra void space after removing the coordinated DMF molecule, in which fluorinated groups line the cavity (Figure , ). The framework topology may be reduced by viewing the zinc cluster as a hexacoordinate antiprism in which four zinc atoms are connected to six carboxylate groups of 1. Figure  illustrates one octahedron bound to six organic building blocks, and the repetition of the same unit in three dimensions results in a framework, which is complicated by the presence of two identical, interpenetrating strands ().

elements.content: CO2 sorption kinetics of FMOF-2 at room temperature. Notice the step sorption at 15 bar and selectivity between CO2 and methane was clear.

elements.content: Thermal analysis of FMOF-2 shows 22% of weight loss between room temperature and 220 °C and corresponds to the loss of coordinated DMF and trapped ethanol molecules (). The surface area of FMOF-2 was obtained by performing N2 adsorption at 77 K. A typical type I isotherm with 378 m2 g−1 of surface area with a microporous nature was found (Figure and ). Gas sorption experiments using various gases at room temperature were performed by means of an HPVA-100 volumetric device. FMOF-2 (∼177 mg) was placed in a sample chamber and activated at 210 °C under a vacuum for several hours prior to the sorption measurements. Low pressure experiments were performed by dosing in the sample chamber 0.1 bar of CO2 every 10 min. The volume adsorbed per gram of material was plotted against the pressure (Figure ). At this pressure (1 bar), the calculated weight percentage was found to be close to 4.5 wt %. The measurements were repeated several times by evacuating the sample and pressurizing with CO2 again. The same weight percentage was obtained within ± 5%. The absence of hysteresis during desorption of CO2 has been found to be very common for microporous materials. In addition, the absence of a saturation point at 1 bar in the CO2 sorption plot suggests that FMOF-2 may show higher adsorption values at high pressure; therefore, we conducted high pressure experiments with CO2 at ambient conditions. The measurements were repeated by evacuating the sample and pressurizing with CO2; a type I relationship with a step in the adsorption isotherm of CO2 at approximately 15 bar was observed (Figure ). Although not common, such a step during the absorption of gases has been observed in similar systems. At 30 bar, the calculated CO2 weight percentage in FMOF-2 was found to be 22% (5.1 mmol/g), which is relatively low compared to other MOF’s reported in the literature such as MOF-177 (33.5 mmol/g at 42 bar) and MIL-101c (40 mmol/g at 50 bar). In order to get some insight into the mechanism behind the CO2 step adsorption, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments using variable temperature and pressure were performed. The PXRD analysis of freshly synthesized FMOF-2 at variable temperatures under a vacuum indicates considerable change in the powder pattern between 120 and 140 °C. This behavior could be ascribed to the framework contraction upon solvent removal (). In addition, it was not possible to generate the original phase by simply returning to the original temperature. Pressurizing the sample up to 500 psi of CO2 at room temperature did not produce transformation back to the original pattern as expected (). Nevertheless, changes observed in the variable temperature PXRD measurements and the step in the adsorption isotherm in the CO2 sorption experiments all suggest the breathing motion of FMOF-2 upon solvent loss and CO2 inclusion. Several experiments were repeated on a freshly synthesized sample to rule out the possibility of experimental error, and CO2 sorption experiments showed a step adsorption between 15 and 20 bar. Additionally, the apparent high flexibility of metal coordination may allow large framework expansion or contraction without any apparent bond breaking. The same material was explored further to identify the selectivity toward nitrogen and methane. Experiments with all pure gases on these materials at low pressures (1 bar) showed very little or no uptake of N2 or CH4 (Figures and ). The selective sorption of CO2 over N2 and CH4 may be due to a combination of small pore size and selective binding to the walls of the framework. The latter is particularly important since perfluorinated compounds have been proven to show remarkable favorable electrostatic interactions with CO2. On the basis of the selectivity between CO2 over methane and nitrogen, we tested FMOF-2 toward H2S and SO2. The gas sorption experiments were carried out using a custom built volumetric analyzer loaded with a known amount of FMOF-2. The pressure drop was recorded as a function of time, and the calculated weight capacities of SO2 and H2S at 1 bar pressure and room temperature were found to be 14.0 and 8.3%, which is comparable to the MOFs reported in the literature (Figure ). In addition, both gas adsorption/desorption plots show hysteresis being particularly clear for SO2 showing a step at around 1.2 bar as observed for CO2 absorption at high pressure. These results confirm once again the breathing motion of FMOF-2 upon gas absorption and desorption. In order to check the structural stability of FMOF-2 after H2S and SO2 experiments, PXRD measurments under pressure were performed, which indicate no change in the PXRD pattern of FMOF-2 and confirm the structural stability (). In order to understand the breathing motion of the FMOF-2 upon solvent removal and gas inclusion, several experiments were conducted using single crystal X-ray diffraction at high pressures of CO2 gas but these were unsuccessful.
elements.clean_text: Thermal analysis of FMOF-2 shows 22% of weight loss between room temperature and 220 °C and corresponds to the loss of coordinated DMF and trapped ethanol molecules (). The surface area of FMOF-2 was obtained by performing N2 adsorption at 77 K. A typical type I isotherm with 378 m2 g-1 of surface area with a microporous nature was found (Figure  and ). Gas sorption experiments using various gases at room temperature were performed by means of an HPVA-100 volumetric device. FMOF-2 (~177 mg) was placed in a sample chamber and activated at 210 °C under a vacuum for several hours prior to the sorption measurements. Low pressure experiments were performed by dosing in the sample chamber 0.1 bar of CO2 every 10 min. The volume adsorbed per gram of material was plotted against the pressure (Figure ). At this pressure (1 bar), the calculated weight percentage was found to be close to 4.5 wt %. The measurements were repeated several times by evacuating the sample and pressurizing with CO2 again. The same weight percentage was obtained within ± 5%. The absence of hysteresis during desorption of CO2 has been found to be very common for microporous materials. In addition, the absence of a saturation point at 1 bar in the CO2 sorption plot suggests that FMOF-2 may show higher adsorption values at high pressure; therefore, we conducted high pressure experiments with CO2 at ambient conditions. The measurements were repeated by evacuating the sample and pressurizing with CO2; a type I relationship with a step in the adsorption isotherm of CO2 at approximately 15 bar was observed (Figure ). Although not common, such a step during the absorption of gases has been observed in similar systems. At 30 bar, the calculated CO2 weight percentage in FMOF-2 was found to be 22% (5.1 mmol/g), which is relatively low compared to other MOF's reported in the literature such as MOF-177 (33.5 mmol/g at 42 bar) and MIL-101c (40 mmol/g at 50 bar). In order to get some insight into the mechanism behind the CO2 step adsorption, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments using variable temperature and pressure were performed. The PXRD analysis of freshly synthesized FMOF-2 at variable temperatures under a vacuum indicates considerable change in the powder pattern between 120 and 140 °C. This behavior could be ascribed to the framework contraction upon solvent removal (). In addition, it was not possible to generate the original phase by simply returning to the original temperature. Pressurizing the sample up to 500 psi of CO2 at room temperature did not produce transformation back to the original pattern as expected (). Nevertheless, changes observed in the variable temperature PXRD measurements and the step in the adsorption isotherm in the CO2 sorption experiments all suggest the breathing motion of FMOF-2 upon solvent loss and CO2 inclusion. Several experiments were repeated on a freshly synthesized sample to rule out the possibility of experimental error, and CO2 sorption experiments showed a step adsorption between 15 and 20 bar. Additionally, the apparent high flexibility of metal coordination may allow large framework expansion or contraction without any apparent bond breaking. The same material was explored further to identify the selectivity toward nitrogen and methane. Experiments with all pure gases on these materials at low pressures (1 bar) showed very little or no uptake of N2 or CH4 (Figures  and ). The selective sorption of CO2 over N2 and CH4 may be due to a combination of small pore size and selective binding to the walls of the framework. The latter is particularly important since perfluorinated compounds have been proven to show remarkable favorable electrostatic interactions with CO2. On the basis of the selectivity between CO2 over methane and nitrogen, we tested FMOF-2 toward H2S and SO2. The gas sorption experiments were carried out using a custom built volumetric analyzer loaded with a known amount of FMOF-2. The pressure drop was recorded as a function of time, and the calculated weight capacities of SO2 and H2S at 1 bar pressure and room temperature were found to be 14.0 and 8.3%, which is comparable to the MOFs reported in the literature (Figure ). In addition, both gas adsorption/desorption plots show hysteresis being particularly clear for SO2 showing a step at around 1.2 bar as observed for CO2 absorption at high pressure. These results confirm once again the breathing motion of FMOF-2 upon gas absorption and desorption. In order to check the structural stability of FMOF-2 after H2S and SO2 experiments, PXRD measurments under pressure were performed, which indicate no change in the PXRD pattern of FMOF-2 and confirm the structural stability (). In order to understand the breathing motion of the FMOF-2 upon solvent removal and gas inclusion, several experiments were conducted using single crystal X-ray diffraction at high pressures of CO2 gas but these were unsuccessful.

elements.content: Uptake of SO2 (red) and H2S (black) in FMOF-2. Notice the step adsorption at 1.5 bar in SO2.
elements.clean_text: 5  Uptake of SO2 (red) and H2S (black) in FMOF-2. Notice the step adsorption at 1.5 bar in SO2.

elements.content: In summary, utilizing fluorinated 2,2-bis(4-carboxyphenyl)hexafluoropropane, we have synthesized a novel three-dimensional MOF via metal ligand coordination. The self-assembly of FMOF-2 results in an interesting 2-fold interpentrated molecular box with expansion and contraction of the framework upon solvent removal and gas inclusion. In addition, FMOF-2 shows high selectivity for CO2 over N2 and CH4 as well as for H2S and SO2. Further investigations on related FMOFs are in progress to better understand the breathing motion of these frameworks.
elements.clean_text: In summary, utilizing fluorinated 2,2-bis(4-carboxyphenyl)hexafluoropropane, we have synthesized a novel three-dimensional MOF via metal ligand coordination. The self-assembly of FMOF-2 results in an interesting 2-fold interpentrated molecular box with expansion and contraction of the framework upon solvent removal and gas inclusion. In addition, FMOF-2 shows high selectivity for CO2 over N2 and CH4 as well as for H2S and SO2. Further investigations on related FMOFs are in progress to better understand the breathing motion of these frameworks.

metadata.title: Gas-Induced Expansion and Contraction of a Fluorinated Metal−Organic Framework
